Award.AwardTitle: Plant Signaling: Molecular Pathways and Network Integration

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability of plants to change in response to changing environmental conditions is the result of signals and indicators that are sensed by the plant, and then responded to through a complex web of signaling components. We have recently begun to understand many of the parts of this system, but understanding how the whole system works, and how the plant might respond to multiple signals, has so far eluded us. This meeting will bring together scientists from a wide range of fields, including chemistry, molecular biology, genetics and computer science, so that they can interact and develop collaborations that will allow them to advance plant sciences in ways that are very important for our national economy and food supply. One of the focuses of this meeting will be to provide an opportunity for young investigators to share their work and to develop collaborations in this highly interdisciplinary field.

Phenotypic plasticity is the quintessential characteristic of plant development and adaptation under fluctuating environments, and is the result of numerous signal sources (extra-, intra- and intercellular) being sensed, integrated and interpreted by a plethora of signaling components which are interacting in a highly-coordinated manner. Recent advances in molecular and synthetic biology, chemistry and computational approaches have greatly facilitated the discovery of novel signaling pathways as well as providing detailed molecular mechanisms for key components of the existing signaling pathway. However, many have yet to be discovered. This meeting will bring together a diverse community of scientists to interact, collaborate and share novel ideas and will encapsulate the most recent advances in this field, from single molecule chemistry to large-scale network analysis, with an emphasis on research areas such as growth and development, environmental responses and biological interactions in both model and non-model plant species. Ultimately, unraveling the complexity of plant signaling networks will be an important step forward in securing food production in today's rapidly changing environment. The meeting will showcase the contributions of trainees and new investigators and provide an opportunity for career development, fostering networking and initiation of collaborations. It is anticipated that this meeting will provide educational benefits including acquainting trainees and investigators new to field with the state-of-the-art science; and providing critical scientific feedback and career development for trainees and new investigators, including opportunities both to see successful scientists presenting cutting-edge science and to network with prospective mentors and others who might contribute to their scientific and professional development.

Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: KEYSTONE SYMPOSIA ON MOLECULAR AND CELLULAR BIOLOGY

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Keystone Symposia conference on Plant Signaling: Molecular Pathways and Network Integration proposed a new approach to studying novel signaling pathways, which has been made possible by advances in chemical genetics and mathematical modeling.  The general aim of this Keystone Symposium conference was to gain a better understanding on how plants perceive and respond to various cues and stimuli which ultimately have an impact on plant growth and productivity. This conference brought together leaders in plant signaling biology with computational modelers and synthetic biologists to unravel the complexity of plant signaling networks.  The goal of bringing together this unique set of researchers is the hope that new partnerships will lead to important advances in areas such as food production and sustainable crop protection.  Keystone Symposia provided an internationally recognized platform to host conferences, as well as, resources which ensured the success of this conference.  In addition, the conference organizers are well-recognized leaders in the field of plant signaling research.

This conference program contained topics that captured and promoted the exciting new research in the field which could lead to the translation of plant signaling knowledge into new applications.  Understanding the dynamic properties presented by different signaling circuit configurations is of great relevance across biology as this knowledge is essential for developing rational interventions in signaling systems, whether in agriculture, medicine or bio-inspired computational systems.  Moreover, this conference enhanced infrastructure by fostering networking among participants and initiation of collaborations.  This conference also provided the opportunity to acquaint trainees and new investigators to the field with the leading scientist in the field.

At the end of the conference, the conference organizers shared their overall impressions of the meeting. They reported they were impressed with the quality of the science presented in this meeting and thanked all the speakers and all the supporting staff for doing a great job in making this meeting successful. Some of the key outcomes and future directions for the field that were discussed during the meeting included the following:

  • The need to approach plant signaling in a multidisciplinary fashion and thus the importance of forming collaborative networks within the field
  • The importance of nurturing next generation scientists and providing them with platforms to actively take part in discussions

In summary, the conference was a success and the support from the NSF enabled several trainees to attend the conference.  The meeting provided ample opportunity for training and professional development.  Trainees and newer investigators were exposed to dozens of high-quality oral presentations by more senior investigators, who served as role models for high-quality research and communication skills.
